docs.lead_paragraph: The rapist seemed to have no sense that there could be consequences to what he had done. The morning after, the rapist gave his 17-year-old victim money for a cab home and asked her to make sure she locked his door on her way out, after he left for work. Two weeks later, she still did not know whether he had murdered her as well. He had been arrested, but he was refusing to take an AIDS test.

headline.main: South African Victims Face Rapists and H.I.V.

docs.abstract: Article in series, Death and Denial, exploring aspects of HIV epidemic in South Africa, describes plight of rape victims; country has one of world's highest rape rates; in rural KwaZulu/Natal province, there is 40 percent chance that young male rapist is HIV positive; public health system does not provide antiretroviral drug therapy for people with HIV, so infection means virtual certainty of death for many rape victims; by law, accused rapist could refuse blood test; this means that even if drugs were available, young women often would not get them in time; photos; map (L)
